Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Bright and Lightfast Fluorescent Pigments for Paints, Polymers and Inks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the creation of new fluorescent materials that will provide new color technologies to the paint, polymer, and ink industries. These new materials will overcome the undesirable properties of commercial fluorescent pigments, like a tendency to rapidly fade, give weak color strength, and degrade during processing. Besides giving fabrics, packaging, and toys bright, attractive colors, improvements to fluorescent pigments could change several parts of daily life: Brighter paints and signs could improve road and airport safety. Product designers for next-generation consumer electronics will have a new color palette for their newest gadget. Agricultural scientists would have a new tool to study crop treatments. As a result, success in this research project has the potential to claim a share of the multi-billion dollar colorant market, disrupt expectations around fluorescent pigments, bring new products to consumers, and create high-tech jobs. In addition, this project leverages collaboration with academic partners, supporting science and entrepreneurship education of university students and postdoctoral fellows.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project provides a revolutionary solution to a problem that has haunted chemistry for more than 150 years. Existing fluorescent materials are formulated with pigments that have thinly dispersed colorants, which dilutes their color and makes them susceptible to degradation. This is done by necessity, because fluorescent dyes have a tendency to aggregate, causing unwanted color changes and loss of the fluorescence effect. This solution utilizes a bottom-up "self-assembly" strategy to eliminate aggregation and create stable fluorescent solids that maximize the longevity and boldness of the color. This research will study this novel class of fluorescent pigment to gauge its resistance to fading, improved chromaticity, and material performance in realistic conditions. This will be done by measuring changes to fluorescence intensity and color appearance under natural and laboratory-accelerated weathering conditions, and creating test "products" in the form of paints and polymers. These test materials are expected to have stronger color for longer periods of time while still being amenable to commercial processing techniques. In addition, this project is an opportunity to study the behavior of self-assembling materials inside polymer formulations, which is a new research area with broad scientific and commercial potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I SBIR project studied the commercial potential of a new type of fluorescent material known as small molecule ionic isolation lattices (SMILES). Our aim was to determine whether they could be used in the specialized fluorescent pigment segment of the broader commercial polymer colorant market. Our work was centered around studying the physical properties of SMILES in a variety of polymer materials.

 

Fluorescent pigments are special because of a unique optical feature: They can absorb light and then re-emit it. This characteristic is especially obvious when they are exposed to ?black light? (Figure 1). Under sunlight, the human eye perceives fluorescent colors to be especially bold and bright, which makes them the most eye-catching and intense colors that exist. For this reason, they are commonly used in applications where visibility is desired, such as safety clothing (e.g., the bright orange and yellow uniforms of construction crews) or advertising (where fluorescent color can attract customer attention and improve sales). Unfortunately, this beauty comes with a catch: They are difficult to manage. They fade rapidly, must be kept at low loadings, and can rapidly degrade when exposed to the high heat and pressure conditions common in polymer processing. Taken together, this means some businesses are hesitant to use fluorescent color in their products, and represents a loss of potential revenue.

 

Before starting the project, we had interviewed several potential customers who underscored these problems and expressed an interest in a color technology that overcame those issues. A fluorescent pigment that could overcome these issues could have a significant commercial and social impact by creating a whole new world of fluorescent products: Fashion houses and product designers would have a new color palette to create flashy accessories; plastics manufacturers would have better tools to create eye-catching parts. Improvements to driver safety, solar energy, and food production were even possibilities.

 

We believed that SMILES technology provided a solution. Our materials use the same starting materials as existing fluorescent colorants ? fluorescent dyes ? but reprocess them using ?self-assembly?. Self-assembly allows us to control the behavior of the fluorescent dyes and turn them into solid particles. We believed these particles would have several advantages over standard fluorescent technologies: They could be capable of achieving higher loadings, and early data indicated that they faded at a slower rate, which would overcome the two most significant challenges to wider adoption of the technology.

 

Our research project started with the characterization of SMILES fade resistance (a property known as lightfastness). Unfortunately, SMILES did not show a consistent improvement in lightfastness. While a few samples did indeed fade at a slower rate, others showed no improvement or in some cases worse performance. However, at the same time SMILES demonstrated several unexpected features: in addition to being more chemically robust (improved resistance to thermal and chemical stress), SMILES could be processed with a wide range of polymer processing techniques and were significantly brighter than the existing technologies (Figure 2). By the end of the project, we are also able to control the optical properties of the fluorescent material (e.g., what fluorescent color and how bright).

 

These results informed a strategic pivot towards an application that took advantage of these unique properties: Fluorescent instrument calibration. The light emitted from fluorescent dyes is a commonly used signal for a large number of high-tech applications. Specialized scientific instruments are used to detect this signal and convert it into data, but in order to work, the instruments must be calibrated. A good analogy is to imagine that a tool that uses fluorescence is like a piano, and the calibrant is a tuning fork. Until the instrument has been properly tuned, it will not be useful. The ideal ?tuning fork? for fluorescence instruments are solid materials containing fluorescent dyes. The results of our research indicate that the unique properties of SMILES (specifically the control over optical properties) make them perfect for this purpose. We believe this application will expand the efficacy of fluorescence technologies, allowing them to provide more detailed and quantitative data for medical diagnosis and scientific research. We have devoted resources to exploring this opportunity, and have shown that it is technically feasible and has customer pull.
